text: <@U05L8PZD2FM> you mention XM ‘gives up’ is this the reason sometimes inplay you can get matched at prices that XM should have theoretically stopped? If so is this because of the volatility of the market or simply the global load?

elements.text: you mention XM ‘gives up’ is this the reason sometimes inplay you can get matched at prices that XM should have theoretically stopped? If so is this because of the volatility of the market or simply the global load?

text: <@U4H19D1D2> matching and price virtualisation are different processes, matching will always complete otherwise you'd be left with a crossed book. Also 'giving up' applies only to XMXM virtualisation, XM virtualisation is simple and has a completely deterministic runtime so doesn't need a rip cord. The only load that matters is global load, I think we sized the virtualiser to 2 billion price solves per second, sounds like a lot but if you take 1p out of the fav every virtual price in the market needs recomputing. What do you mean by 'getting matched at prices that XM should have theoretically stopped' ?

elements.text: matching and price virtualisation are different processes, matching will always complete otherwise you'd be left with a crossed book. Also 'giving up' applies only to XMXM virtualisation, XM virtualisation is simple and has a completely deterministic runtime so doesn't need a rip cord. The only load that matters is global load, I think we sized the virtualiser to 2 billion price solves per second, sounds like a lot but if you take 1p out of the fav every virtual price in the market needs recomputing. What do you mean by 'getting matched at prices that XM should have theoretically stopped' ?

text: But surely price virtualisation needs to happen for matching? Sometimes inplay it seems as though you can matched prices that XM should have stopped

elements.text: But surely price virtualisation needs to happen for matching? Sometimes inplay it seems as though you can matched prices that XM should have stopped

text: The maths is the same, the process entirely different. Matcher builds ephemeral opposing liquidity on every new order (to match against), virtualiser has to generate virtual prices for every existing priced price on the entire exchange updated after any cycle that changes anything.

elements.text: The maths is the same, the process entirely different. Matcher builds ephemeral opposing liquidity on every new order (to match against), virtualiser has to generate virtual prices for every existing priced price on the entire exchange updated after any cycle that changes anything.

text: So you mean you 'appear' to be able to match into an under round market? This is either because the market is partially priced (some runners have no offers because they got hit or cancelled ahead of you in the cycle) at the point your order is processed and/or because you are only seeing a snapshot of the market not the market after each match.

elements.text: So you mean you 'appear' to be able to match into an under round market? text:
This is obviously very much a philosophical argument but conceptually by using such a probabilistic model you are bypassing a large amount of learning that a generic machine learning model has to do to understand the dynamics of the sport

Also means your model is not a black box and you can directly relate the model parameters to observable factors

text: a gradient boosting model requires very few (if any) assumptions about distributions etc. handles outliers and strange distributions well. handles complicated interactions between features and handles missing data. feature selection is somewhat "built-in." performance is comparable to deep learning algos for simple tabular data

text: So even though the virtual price would not be "visible" at the time of placing a back bet ( with ask price of the best nonvirtual back price), it is possible that BPE  would match my bet at a better virtual price based off of what you've above described as "ephemeral opposing liquidity"?  On the assumption that is true, the values that would appeard as traded volumes in the stream would actually only be shown as money taken from the available to lay cash on the other selections used to generate that virtual price I was matched at? So essentially virtual price matching happens immediately at the better price even though that price is not yet available to see (because of the approx 150 millisecond delay) ?

elements.text: So even though the virtual price would not be "visible" at the time of placing a back bet ( with ask price of the best nonvirtual back price), it is possible that BPE  would match my bet at a better virtual price based off of what you've above described as "ephemeral opposing liquidity"?  On the assumption that is true, the values that would appeard as traded volumes in the stream would actually only be shown as money taken from the available to lay cash on the other selections used to generate that virtual price I was matched at? So essentially virtual price matching happens immediately at the better price even though that price is not yet available to see (because of the approx 150 millisecond delay) ?

text: Matching always happens at the best price available when the new order is picked up by the matcher, doesn't matter if it is matching directly opposing orders or orders made up of multiple indirectly opposing orders (XM/XMXM), nor does it matter what you have seen. Simple non XM example, market is visibly empty. You fire in a bet at 2.0, someone else happens to fire in a directly opposing bet that arrives at the matcher just before you within the same cycle, the orders fully match, the new market view is still empty and market has recorded a trade.

elements.text: Matching always happens at the best price available when the new order is picked up by the matcher, doesn't matter if it is matching directly opposing orders or orders made up of multiple indirectly opposing orders (XM/XMXM), nor does it matter what you have seen. Simple non XM example, market is visibly empty. You fire in a bet at 2.0, someone else happens to fire in a directly opposing bet that arrives at the matcher just before you within the same cycle, the orders fully match, the new market view is still empty and market has recorded a trade.

text: Thanks Joe - so in an XM enabled market, using the same example of 2 users putting orders in (almost) simultaneously, what happens if someone places a back bet of £2 on selection A @ 60.0 and the other places a back bet of £50 on selection B @ 1.01 ? Can you explain the flow of events (sorry for all the question, I just really want to nail down my understanding based on your prior posts) ?

elements.text: Thanks Joe - so in an XM enabled market, using the same example of 2 users putting orders in (almost) simultaneously, what happens if someone places a back bet of £2 on selection A @ 60.0 and the other places a back bet of £50 on selection B @ 1.01 ? Can you explain the flow of events (sorry for all the question, I just really want to nail down my understanding based on your prior posts) ?

text: Assuming a 2 runner market that is empty, say the A bet arrives first, doesn't match and is offered to the market, B bet arrives, matcher looks for opposing liquidity and finds the best price is the A bet inverted, i.e. price 1.0169...,  so records matches on A at 60 and B at 1.01, you can work out the stakes.

elements.text: Assuming a 2 runner market that is empty, say the A bet arrives first, doesn't match and is offered to the market, B bet arrives, matcher looks for opposing liquidity and finds the best price is the A bet inverted, i.e. price 1.0169...,  so records matches on A at 60 and B at 1.01, you can work out the stakes.

???
